name: California
title: Southwestern College unveils personalized path to degree
description:
Southwestern College is launching the first Direct Assessment Competency-Based Education (CBE) program in automotive technology at a California community college.

The program, called CBE Accelerate, is designed to offer a flexible, personalized and career-focused path to a degree for students balancing work, family and other responsibilities.

Two information sessions happened this week to introduce the new program at the Southwestern College Chula Vista and National City campuses.

The sessions introduced students to a revolutionary way to earn an associate’s degree in automotive technology – one that puts real-world skills, flexibility, and student success at the center, the college stated.

The program allows students to learn at their own pace and take exams when ready. It features fully online instruction with flexible scheduling and includes industry-relevant skills along with general education competencies such as critical thinking, communication, problem-solving and quantitative reasoning.

Faculty provide one-on-one feedback and support. The program uses a flat subscription fee per term for both part-time and full-time enrollment, with the option to add more learning at no extra cost if students finish early. There are three terms per year.

The program also integrates virtual reality for hands-on training and offers access to counseling, faculty and student services. It is intended for working adults looking to upskill or change careers, students seeking a flexible and affordable degree path, and individuals interested in automotive technology and innovative education models.

name: California
title: Evolving trajectories of educational expectations and science performance during middle school and STEM degree attainment of youth in adulthood - Humanities and Social Sciences Communications
description: Extensive research has established the positive relationship between youths’ educational expectations and academic performance. However, limited attention has been paid to how the developmental and growth trajectories of educational expectations may dynamically shape the development and growth in science performance during middle school—a critical period for fostering long-term STEM achievement. Leveraging longitudinal panel data from the second-cohort sample of the Longitudinal Study of American Youth (LSAY), this study employs parallel-process latent growth curve modeling (PP-LGCM) to investigate how evolving educational expectations and science performance of youths during early adolescence jointly predict STEM degree attainment in adulthood. Results reveal that the development and growth in educational expectations of youths across middle school years positively drive their corresponding development and growth in science performance. These parallel trajectories collectively and significantly predict youths’ successful graduation with a four-year STEM degree in adulthood, with the developmental and growth trajectories of science performance significantly mediating the relationship. Monte Carlo simulations confirmed the robustness of these findings, demonstrating strong statistical power (>0.80) and minimal bias (<5%) for all focal parameters, with sensitivity analyses indicating model stability across varying sample sizes. The findings underscore the interconnected, cumulative, and progressive nature of academic motivation and science competency during early adolescence in relation to youths’ later STEM achievement, challenging static conceptualizations of these constructs. By framing educational expectations and science learning as dynamic, time-varying processes, this study advances theoretical and methodological approaches to STEM development research. Practical implications highlight the need for holistic educational policies and interventions that nurture both aspirational growth and foundational science competence during formative school years, thereby strengthening pathways to STEM success.
